title: Illustrative Projects
text:
I love  and the culture of collaborative, reproducible and open research that this programming ecosystem promotes.
The projects below include: R code I wrote for analyzing, modelling and visualizing data; workshop materials I have created/presented; and other content (not necessarily related to my core research area).

title: Illustrative Projects
text:
2024

Text analytics project applied to World Bank corpus of Projects‚Äô documents (FY 2001 - 2023)
(WORK IN PROGRESS‚Ä¶)
 Project website |  Source Code
This is an ongoing project I started to learn some NLP (Natural Language Processing) techniques to answer a question that I find extremely interesting and compelling: What is the impact of slogans and catchphrases on policy decisions? These are heavily used in the policy debate and strategic planning and I am curious to explore patterns of their occurrence using project documents as input data. 


Position paper on city government ‚ÄúIdee per Pavia‚Äù (April 2024)
 Project website |  Source Code | (in Italian üáÆüáπ)
This is webpage I created to disseminate a position paper that I co-authored with the members of the Catholic Social Action Office of the Diocese of Pavia (my hometown in Italy). The report is meant as a tool to promote open and constructive dialogue on several urban planning issues and proposals in view of the upcoming municipal elections of June 2024.

title: Illustrative Projects
text:
2022

Exploratory Analysis of EU funds (ERDF, 2014-2020 cycle) spending (November 2022)
 Project website |  Source Code
This is a quick exploration of some EU structural funds aimed at verifying how much Italy has been able to disburse (given amounts planned and deemed eligible) for the 2014-2020 funding cycle. Specifically data were taken from the ESIF 2014-2020 Finance Implementation Details (99js-gm52) dataset, then drilled down to programs under the ERDF (European Regional Development Fund). This was also an opportunity to learn some interective datavisualization tools in R (e.g.¬†reactable).

I am a Policy & Data Analyst, freelance consultant, and  enthusiast.
My consulting services include data and statistical analysis, quantitative program evaluation, and policy analysis. I have extensively applied these skills across different sectors and contexts, working with multilateral development banks, central and local government policy-makers, academic researchers, small firms and non-profit organisations (mostly in Italy üáÆüáπ and in the US üá∫üá∏).
I greatly enjoy teaching and have successfully delivered lectures and workshops on statistics, reproducible data analysis and visualization.  
You can learn more about my background via my CV, take a look at my published work, or peruse some illustrative projects, data tools and other learning experiments.


I am open to collaborate on projects involving data and statistical analysis, program evaluation, or R programming/training.

title: Teaching
text:
Selected materials from my teaching activities, including workshops, seminars, and on the job training I have delivered over the years.












Introductory workshop on ‚ÄúR for Biostatistics‚Äù (July 2024)
 Project website |  Source Code
This website collects the materials for a four day workshop organized by MITGEST Doctoral Network in July 2024. The workshop is offered as part of a summer school for EU doctoral biology students, hosted by the Radboud Center for Mitochondrial Medicine, in Nijmegen, Netherlands. My sister (M. Chiara Mimmi, Ph.D.), is in charge of the workshop, while I co-created the materials for the R practice sessions, plus the course website.
Seminar on ‚ÄúReproducible Data Analysis‚Äù (July 2023)
 Slides
This seminar (titled Principi, tecniche e strumenti per l‚Äôanalisi riproducibile dei dati) is an introduction to reproducible data analysis, I offered to the PNRR Unit, within the Presidency of the Ministries Council, Rome. The seminar covers principles, techniques, and tools for reproducible data analysis.
Lessons learned from a pilot study on ‚ÄúWillingness to pay for legal electricity among slum residents‚Äù (April 2012)
 Slides
This lesson was an internal training initiatives in which I shared with my team the World Bank some lessons learned from a pilot study conducted on slum electrification in Mumbai. The lesson focused on the sampling methodology and the estimation of willingness to pay for infrastructure services, based on a household survey conducted in 4 urban slums of Mumbai.
